main event: On March 2, 1955, in Spooner, Wisconsin, a civilian observed a circular aluminum-colored disc-shaped object at a very high altitude, moving at a very high rate of speed from south to north, reversing its direction, and disappearing heading north after approximately 15 seconds of observation.
interesting points: The object appeared to be approximately half the size of the moon and traveled at estimated speeds of 500 to 1,500 mph, with constant size and shape.
The observer reported clear weather conditions with thin light cirrus clouds, with wind aloft at different altitudes.
The observer had no previous experience in aircraft recognition but had observed a similar object in 1938 at the same location.
The object was observed at night, and the observer noticed it to be bluish-white in color.
No physical evidence was reported, but the observer was able to provide specific geographical coordinates of the observation location.
